body:
Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1697/

Something to be aware of - This includes the platform specific cuda jars for which SystemML was built on. 

In an offline discussion with @niketanpansare, he said it was ok to have Linux jcuda native jars, because that would probably be the more widely used platform. For other platforms, we could provide instructions for their setup.

Another option would be to just include ALL or.jcuda jars for all platforms. This would blow up the `extra` jar size. Also, I'd need to test if that would work.

@nakul02 The jcuda jars are included likely as resource rather than `compile` by this PR.  Also, I don't see jcuda classes. Here is the content of `extra` jar:
```
lib/
lib/jcuda-0.8.0.jar
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/BaseDMLGenerator$$anonfun$invoke$2.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/Caffe2DML$$anonfun$org$apache$sysml$api$dl$Caffe2DML$$backward$1.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/Caffe2DMLModel$$anonfun$getPredictionScript$8.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/CaffeNetwork$.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/DMLGenerator$$anonfun$initWeights$1.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/HasWeight$class.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/IsLossLayer.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/LearningRatePolicy.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/Nesterov$.class
org/apache/sysml/api/dl/Nesterov.class
...
```

Hence,  the following python code throws an error `java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: jcuda.runtime.JCuda`:
```python
import numpy as np
from sklearn import datasets
from systemml.mllearn import LinearRegression
# Load the diabetes dataset
diabetes = datasets.load_diabetes()
# Use only one feature
diabetes_X = diabetes.data[:, np.newaxis, 2]
# Split the data into training/testing sets
X_train = diabetes_X[:-20]
X_test = diabetes_X[-20:]
# Split the targets into training/testing sets
y_train = diabetes.target[:-20]
y_test = diabetes.target[-20:]
# Create linear regression object
regr = LinearRegression(spark, fit_intercept=True, C=float("inf"), solver='direct-solve').setGPU(True).setForceGPU(True).setStatistics(True)
# Train the model using the training sets
regr.fit(X_train, y_train)
```

For reference, on GitHub, the 0.8.0 tag does not include the MIT LICENSE file that exists on the master branch. However, based on the discussion at https://github.com/jcuda/jcuda-main/issues/18, 0.8.0 is indeed MIT licensed and the license file is at http://jcuda.org/License.txt.
Thanks @deroneriksson, I shall merge.

ping @nakul02. 
Could you please review this PR.
I think only the above two files contains the old `if ( ) else { }` style and have been fixed, and I've gone through all the algorithms.
@deroneriksson can you assign me to [systemml-888](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-888), until my systemml-1437 is reviewed and tested, I will implement the algorithm.

Great @j143, I've assigned SYSTEMML-888 to you. Note in the comment that I supplied that there is a PNMF example at http://apache.github.io/systemml/spark-mlcontext-programming-guide.html#define-a-kernel-for-poisson-nonnegative-matrix-factorization-pnmf-in-dml that is probably the best starting point for the creation of a PNMF.dml file.
Thanks @krishnakalyan3, I shall merge

This is good work! Documentation is always appreciated.

Ping @asurve - this document should help with running the perf tests using @krishnakalyan3's perf test script.

LGTM. Thank you @krishnakalyan3. I'll merge.

Note, I'll just make a minor update of "[OPTIONAL] Location to read the true label matrix Y" to "[OPTIONAL] Location to read the true label matrix Y. Only needed for evaluating performance (accuracy, confusion) of the model."
@nakul02 thanks for the review.

@krishnakalyan3 - I would not expect you to keep this PR open till the end of GSoC. It should be in a good enough shape to be commit-able right now. With each phase, you should update it and commit it as part of that phase. 
Let me know if you think this is commit-able right now.
~@nakul02, yes its commit-able~. Will update this document after a minor bug fix.

I believe there may be some more nested if-else's that need to be cleaned up. Could you please check on the following?

The failing test is the following: `R = W*(2*(U%*%t(V)));`.
The opcode `wumm` changed to `wdivmm` with an additional argument of -1, and with the "multiply by literal 2" appearing above `wdivmm`. Anyone knows what this means?
Can an Admin verify this patch?

@j143 indeed, see the previous comment. Do you know what `wumm` and `wdivmm` are?  I believe that this happened because the `2*` scalar multiply moved around. I'd like to understand what the conditions for `wumm` are and why this is better than `wdivmm` so that I can try to work with it in the ordering of inputs to an element-wise multiply.
here is an overview https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/docs/devdocs/MatrixMultiplicationOperators.txt; sorry for the delay - I'll make a pass over this PR tonight.

Also, see the online version at http://apache.github.io/systemml/engine-dev-guide.html#complex-matrix-multiplication-operators and http://apache.github.io/systemml/engine-dev-guide.html#core-matrix-multiplication-primitives

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1740/

@mboehm7 Could you help have a look at this issue? More information can be found at [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1762). The revised codes in this commit just wants to show the error location.

Okay, looks like the new element-wise rewrite order no longer meets pattern 2: `(W*sop(U%*%t(V),c))` where `sop` is `*` and `c` is `2`.
Instead it meets pattern 7: `W*(U%*%t(V))`.

This happens because we moved the `*2` to the outside, as in `( W*(U%*%t(V)) ) * 2`.
I guess this new pattern is a bit less efficient because the *2 is an extra operation after the wdivmm.
But if I were to try special casing it, it would be weird to stick the scalar in the middle of the two matrix multiplies in general. So I would have to look for exactly this pattern.
Or I could try modifying wumm to recognize if there is a "multiply by constant" outside the `W*(U%*%t(V))` which we could absorb into it.
sure, I'll have a look; thanks for catching this @feihugis
